SSR Test Results

Server Rendering

Server render time: Loading...

This timestamp was generated during the initial render (potentially on the server)

Client Rendering

Client hydrated: No

Client render time: Loading...

This state is only updated after client-side JavaScript runs

Interpretation

  • If the page is server-rendered, the initial HTML will contain the server timestamp, but "Client hydrated" will show "No" until JavaScript runs
  • If the page is client-rendered only, you'll briefly see no content or placeholder content until JavaScript runs
  • After hydration, both timestamps will be visible, but they'll be different if server rendering occurred
  • You can also check the page source (View Source) to see if the HTML contains the server timestamp

Advanced SSR Test Results

Technical Details

Server Render Time:Loading...
Client Hydrated:No
Client Render Time:Loading...
Window Object:Not Available
Document Object:Not Available
Navigator Object:Not Available
User Agent:
Loading...

How to Verify SSR

  1. View Page Source: Right-click on the page and select "View Page Source" (not "Inspect"). If you see the server timestamp and "Client hydrated: No" in the HTML source, the page was server-rendered.
  2. Disable JavaScript: Temporarily disable JavaScript in your browser and reload the page. If content still appears, it's server-rendered.
  3. Network Tab: In browser DevTools, check the Network tab and look at the initial HTML response. Server-rendered content will be in the HTML.
  4. Time Difference: After the page loads, compare the server and client timestamps. If they differ, the initial render was on the server.

Important Note for Netlify Deployment

When deployed on Netlify, this site will serve pre-rendered static HTML files. This means the HTML is generated at build time, not for each request. While this appears as "server-rendered" content, it's actually statically generated during the build process, not true server-side rendering that happens on each request.

Why Clean Your HTML?

When copying content from Google Docs to WordPress, you often encounter unwanted formatting that can break your website's layout. Our tool removes unnecessary HTML tags, inline styles, and attributes while preserving the essential formatting you need.

Perfect for Content Creators

Whether you're a blogger, content writer, or WordPress developer, our tool streamlines your workflow. Write in Google Docs, clean the HTML with our tool, and paste directly into WordPress. No more formatting headaches!

How It Works

Our HTML cleaner uses advanced algorithms to strip out unnecessary formatting while preserving the structure and meaning of your content. It's specifically designed to work with WordPress, ensuring your content looks perfect on your website.
